sip_enable_inflation.title: Inflation can materially reduce real outcomes
sip_enable_inflation.body: If this SIP is for a long-term goal, it helps to view the result in today's value. Turning on inflation shows a more realistic (inflation-adjusted) maturity.

sip_add_initial_lumpsum.title: Add an initial lump sum (optional)
sip_add_initial_lumpsum.body: A small initial lump sum can give compounding a head start. Try adding ~{{amount}}.

sip_add_yearly_lumpsum.title: Add a yearly top-up (optional)
sip_add_yearly_lumpsum.body: If you get annual bonus / irregular cashflow, try adding a yearly lump sum of ~{{amount}}.

sip_return_sensitivity.title: Sensitivity to returns (quick range)
sip_return_sensitivity.body: With the same contributions, a small change in return assumption can change outcomes meaningfully. Your maturity moves from ~{{maturity}} to ~{{low}} (lower-return) or ~{{high}} (higher-return).

sip_stepup_impact_on.title: Step-up impact
sip_stepup_impact_on.body: With a step-up of {{stepUpPct}} per year, maturity is ~{{maturity}}. Without step-up (same starting SIP), it would be ~{{noStep}}.

sip_stepup_impact_off.title: Step-up can materially increase outcomes
sip_stepup_impact_off.body: With step-up off, maturity is ~{{maturity}}. In a quick check, adding a yearly step-up can increase maturity by ~{{delta}} (vs no step-up ~{{noStep}}).

sip_timing_impact.title: Contribute earlier in the cycle (if possible)
sip_timing_impact.body: For {{frequency}} contributions, making deposits at the start of the cycle can increase compounding time. In a quick check, maturity improves from ~{{maturity}} to ~{{timingStart}}.

sip_goal_gap.title: Projected maturity is below target
sip_goal_gap.body: Target is ~{{target}} and projected maturity is ~{{maturity}}. To close the gap, you can increase SIP amount, extend the tenure, or enable a yearly step-up.

sip_inflation_goal_uplift.title: Inflation raises the goal amount
sip_inflation_goal_uplift.body: Your goal is ~{{today}} in today's money. With inflation, the implied target at the end of ~{{years}} years is ~{{future}}.

sip_existing_corpus_dominates.title: Most contribution is coming from existing corpus
sip_existing_corpus_dominates.body: You added an initial lump sum of ~{{lumpSum}}. Only ~{{sipSharePct}}% of total contributions are coming via SIP. If you want the plan to rely more on periodic investing, consider increasing the SIP amount or enabling step-up.

sip_real_value_drop.title: Real (inflation-adjusted) value is much lower
sip_real_value_drop.body: Nominal maturity is ~{{maturity}}, but in today's money it's ~{{maturityAdj}}. Consider increasing SIP / step-up or reviewing the goal in real terms.

sip_tax_enable.title: Enable taxation for post-tax insights
sip_tax_enable.body: Turn on Taxation in Settings to see an estimated post-tax maturity (capital gains) and the tax drag on returns.

sip_tax_post_tax_maturity.title: Estimated post-tax maturity (capital gains)
sip_tax_post_tax_maturity.body: Assuming Equity MF {{hold}}{{exempt}}: gains ~{{gain}}, taxable gains ~{{taxableGain}}, tax ~{{tax}} at ~{{rate}}%. Maturity ~{{maturity}} (post-tax ~{{postTax}}).

sip_tax_drag.title: Tax drag on gains
sip_tax_drag.body: Estimated tax could reduce your gains by ~{{drag}}% (Equity MF {{hold}}).

bond_enable_inflation.title: Enable inflation (real yield)
bond_enable_inflation.body: Inflation reduces real returns. Turn on inflation to see the inflation-adjusted (real) yield/return.

sgb_total_return_context.title: What is driving your SGB outcome
sgb_total_return_context.body: Over ~{{years}} years, your estimate totals ~{{totalValue}} on an investment of ~{{invested}}.

sgb_coupon_share.title: Coupons are a smaller part of SGB returns
sgb_coupon_share.body: In your projection, coupons contribute ~{{totalCoupons}} (~{{couponSharePct}}% of total value). Most of the outcome comes from gold price movement. If gold CAGR is uncertain for your horizon, re-check the CAGR input and view the range.

sgb_real_return.title: Projected return may not beat inflation
sgb_real_return.body: With inflation at ~{{infl}}%, your estimated annualized return is ~{{effCagrPct}}% (real ~{{real}}%). Consider whether your gold CAGR assumption fits your goal horizon, or run a lower-CAGR scenario.

bond_current_yield_vs_ytm.title: Cash yield vs total return (YTM) can diverge
bond_current_yield_vs_ytm.body: Your annual coupon cashflow is ~{{couponCashPerYear}}. That is ~{{currentYieldPct}}% of the clean price, while YTM is ~{{ytmPct}}%. If current yield is higher than YTM, part of your return is offset by buying at a premium; if lower, YTM relies more on price appreciation to face value by maturity.

bond_premium.title: You are paying a premium to face value
bond_premium.body: Your clean price (~{{clean}}) is ~{{premiumPct}}% above face (~{{face}}). If you hold to maturity you still redeem at face; the premium is recovered via lower total return (YTM) vs coupon rate. If you may sell before maturity, a yield rise can compress the premium faster.

bond_discount.title: You are buying below face value
bond_discount.body: Your clean price (~{{clean}}) is ~{{discountPct}}% below face (~{{face}}). Part of your YTM comes from pull-to-par (price moving towards face value) if held to maturity.

bond_yield_sensitivity.title: Price sensitivity to yield changes
bond_yield_sensitivity.body: If market yield moves by ±0.50%, the estimated dirty price shifts from ~{{baseDirty}} to ~{{up}} (higher yield) or ~{{down}} (lower yield). If you may sell before maturity, this is the primary risk to plan for.

bond_accrued_interest.title: Accrued interest affects what you actually pay
bond_accrued_interest.body: Your accrued interest is ~{{ai}}. Even if you quote a clean price, settlement typically happens at dirty price (clean + accrued). If you are comparing deals, compare dirty prices on the same settlement date.

bond_real_yield.title: Inflation may erase most of the real yield
bond_real_yield.body: With inflation at ~{{infl}}%, your approximate real yield is ~{{real}}%/yr (YTM ~{{ytmPct}}%). If this is a long-term goal, consider whether you need some growth allocation alongside the bond bucket.

fd_high_rate.title: FD rate looks unusually high
fd_high_rate.body: You entered {{r}}%. Typical median for this tenure is ~{{median}}%. If this is a small finance/NBFC issuer, check credit rating, DICGC coverage, and lock-in terms.

fd_low_rate.title: FD rate looks low vs market
fd_low_rate.body: You entered {{r}}%. Typical median for this tenure is ~{{median}}%. You may be leaving returns on the table—compare rates across banks for the same tenure and payout type.

fd_inflation_warning.title: Inflation may wipe out real returns
fd_inflation_warning.body: With inflation at ~{{infl}}%, your real return is roughly ~{{real}}%/yr before tax. Consider whether this FD is for safety/liquidity vs growth.

fd_post_tax_yield.title: Post-tax FD yield is what matters
fd_post_tax_yield.body: At {{r}}% nominal, your estimated post-tax yield is ~{{postTax}}%/yr using slab {{slab}}%{{assumption}}{{regime}}.

fd_post_tax_real_negative.title: Post-tax returns may not beat inflation
fd_post_tax_real_negative.body: With inflation at ~{{infl}}%, your post-tax real return is roughly ~{{postTaxReal}}%/yr. Consider whether you need more growth-oriented instruments for long-term goals.

fd_taxable.title: FD interest is taxable
fd_taxable.body: FD interest is generally taxed as per your income slab (TDS may apply based on thresholds).{{regime}} Factor post-tax returns when comparing to alternatives.{{assumption}}

fd_tax_enable.title: Enable taxation for accurate post-tax yield
fd_tax_enable.body: Turn on Taxation in Settings to compute post-tax returns using your slab (instead of a generic assumption).

rd_rate_context.title: RD rate context
rd_rate_context.body: For ~{{years}} years (using FD market bands as proxy): {{context}}.

rd_high_rate.title: RD rate looks unusually high
rd_high_rate.body: You entered {{r}}%. Typical median for this tenure is ~{{median}}%. If this is a small finance/NBFC issuer, check credit rating, withdrawal rules, and lock-in terms.

rd_low_rate.title: RD rate looks low vs market
rd_low_rate.body: You entered {{r}}%. Typical median for this tenure is ~{{median}}%. Consider comparing rates across banks for the same tenure and compounding frequency.

rd_inflation_warning.title: Inflation may wipe out real returns
rd_inflation_warning.body: With inflation at ~{{infl}}%, your real return is roughly ~{{real}}%/yr before tax. RD is great for disciplined saving, but don’t expect strong real growth at low spreads.

rd_post_tax_yield.title: Post-tax RD yield is what matters
rd_post_tax_yield.body: At {{r}}% nominal, your estimated post-tax yield is ~{{postTax}}%/yr using slab {{slab}}%{{assumption}}{{regime}}.

rd_post_tax_real_negative.title: Post-tax returns may not beat inflation
rd_post_tax_real_negative.body: With inflation at ~{{infl}}%, your post-tax real return is roughly ~{{postTaxReal}}%/yr. Consider whether RD is for discipline/cashflow vs long-term growth.

rd_taxable.title: RD interest is taxable
rd_taxable.body: RD interest is generally taxed as per your income slab.{{regime}} Consider post-tax returns when comparing to alternatives.{{assumption}}

rd_tax_enable.title: Enable taxation for accurate post-tax yield
rd_tax_enable.body: Turn on Taxation in Settings to compute post-tax returns using your slab (instead of a generic assumption).

ppf_enable_inflation.title: Enable inflation (real value)
ppf_enable_inflation.body: Inflation reduces real purchasing power. Turn on inflation to view maturity value in today's money.

ppf_lock_in.title: Lock-in is long
ppf_lock_in.body: PPF is typically locked for ~{{lockIn}} years. A {{term}}-year horizon may not match the product rules and liquidity constraints.

ppf_extension_blocks_aligned.title: Extension planning after maturity
ppf_extension_blocks_aligned.body: You selected ~{{term}} years. After the initial ~{{lockIn}}-year lock-in, PPF extensions are typically in 5-year blocks. Your horizon aligns (~{{extra}} years ≈ {{blocks}} blocks).

ppf_extension_blocks_unaligned.title: Extension planning after maturity
ppf_extension_blocks_unaligned.body: You selected ~{{term}} years. After the initial ~{{lockIn}}-year lock-in, PPF extensions are typically in 5-year blocks. Consider aligning to 5-year blocks after maturity for cleaner planning.

ppf_annual_cap.title: Annual contribution cap
ppf_annual_cap.body: PPF annual contribution is typically capped at ~₹{{maxAnnual}}. Your planned annual contribution (~₹{{annual}}) exceeds this cap.

ppf_cap_util_low.title: You are using a small part of the annual limit
ppf_cap_util_low.body: Your planned annual contribution is ~₹{{annual}}, which is ~{{utilPct}}% of the typical PPF annual cap (~₹{{maxAnnual}}). If your goal is long-term, tax-free compounding, consider increasing contributions (subject to cashflow).

ppf_cap_util_high.title: Good use of PPF annual limit
ppf_cap_util_high.body: Your planned annual contribution is ~₹{{annual}} (~{{utilPct}}% of the typical cap ~₹{{maxAnnual}}). This helps you benefit more from tax-free compounding.

ppf_inflation_warning.title: Inflation may reduce real growth
ppf_inflation_warning.body: With inflation at ~{{infl}}%, real return is roughly ~{{real}}%/yr. PPF is great for stability and tax efficiency, but may not build strong real wealth at low spreads.

ppf_tax_eee.title: Tax treatment is EEE
ppf_tax_eee.body: PPF is typically EEE: contributions (within limits), interest, and maturity proceeds are generally tax-free.

ssy_enable_inflation.title: Enable inflation (real value)
ssy_enable_inflation.body: Inflation reduces real purchasing power. Turn on inflation to view maturity value in today's money.

ssy_maturity_context.title: Maturity timeline
ssy_maturity_context.body: SSY typically matures in ~{{maturityYears}} years from account opening. With girl age ~{{age}}, maturity is around age ~{{maturityAge}}.

ssy_age_18_milestone.title: Age-18 milestone planning
ssy_age_18_milestone.body: Girl is ~{{age}} now. Age 18 is ~{{yearsTo18}} years away. If this is meant for higher education, align contributions and expectations to that milestone (maturity is later).

ssy_cap_util_low.title: You are using a small part of the annual limit
ssy_cap_util_low.body: Your planned annual contribution is ~₹{{annual}}, which is ~{{utilPct}}% of the typical SSY annual cap (~₹{{maxAnnual}}). If you want to maximize the tax-free compounding benefit, consider increasing contributions (subject to your cashflow).

ssy_cap_util_high.title: Good use of SSY annual limit
ssy_cap_util_high.body: Your planned annual contribution is ~₹{{annual}} (~{{utilPct}}% of the typical cap ~₹{{maxAnnual}}). This helps you benefit more from tax-free compounding.

ssy_annual_cap.title: Annual contribution cap
ssy_annual_cap.body: SSY annual contribution is typically capped at ~₹{{maxAnnual}}. Your planned annual contribution (~₹{{annual}}) exceeds this cap.

ssy_inflation_warning.title: Inflation may reduce real growth
ssy_inflation_warning.body: With inflation at ~{{infl}}%, real return is roughly ~{{real}}%/yr. SSY is designed for safety and tax efficiency; consider complementing with higher-growth instruments for long horizons if needed.

ssy_tax_eee.title: Tax treatment is EEE
ssy_tax_eee.body: SSY is typically EEE: contributions (within limits), interest, and maturity proceeds are generally tax-free.

nps_enable_inflation.title: Enable inflation (real value)
nps_enable_inflation.body: Inflation reduces real purchasing power. Turn on inflation to view outcomes in today's money.

nps_return_very_high.title: Return assumption looks aggressive
nps_return_very_high.body: You entered {{r}}%/yr, which is quite high for long-term planning. Consider running a sensitivity check with {{maxRealistic}}% or lower as well.

nps_short_horizon.title: Short horizon increases risk
nps_short_horizon.body: With only ~{{years}} years to retirement, market volatility can materially affect outcomes. Consider conservative assumptions and asset allocation.

nps_return_sensitivity.title: Market-linked sensitivity (quick check)
nps_return_sensitivity.body: A small change in return assumptions can move outcomes meaningfully. In a quick scenario check, your corpus changes from ~{{corpus}} to ~{{low}} (lower-return) or ~{{high}} (higher-return).

nps_small_corpus_exemption.title: Small corpus: full withdrawal likely allowed
nps_small_corpus_exemption.body: Your estimated corpus (~{{corpus}}) is within the small-corpus threshold (~{{threshold}}). Under current rules, full lump-sum withdrawal may be allowed (no mandatory annuity).

nps_intermediate_slab.title: Exit slab may force partial annuity
nps_intermediate_slab.body: Your corpus falls in a slab where rules can force a partial annuity purchase even if you prefer lump sum. Review the lump-sum vs annuity split shown in the result.

nps_lumpsum_context.title: Lump sum vs annuity trade-off
nps_lumpsum_context.body: Your estimated lump sum is ~{{lumpSum}} (out of ~{{corpus}}). Higher annuity purchase increases pension but reduces investable lump sum.

nps_annuity_high.title: High annuity purchase reduces flexibility
nps_annuity_high.body: You are allocating ~{{effectivePct}}% to annuity. This can increase pension but reduces liquidity and lump-sum flexibility.

nps_annuity_tax_note.title: Annuity is typically taxable
nps_annuity_tax_note.body: Annuity income is generally taxable as per slab. You set annuity purchase at {{annPct}}% with annuity rate {{annRate}}%. Factor post-tax pension when planning.

nps_inflation_warning.title: Inflation may erode real wealth
nps_inflation_warning.body: With inflation at ~{{infl}}%, your real return assumption is only ~{{real}}%/yr. For retirement planning, run scenarios with higher inflation / lower returns too.

nps_real_corpus.title: Inflation-adjusted corpus at retirement
nps_real_corpus.body: In today's money, your retirement corpus is ~{{realCorpus}} (after ~{{years}} years). Use this to compare against today’s goals/expenses.

epf_enable_inflation.title: Enable inflation (real value)
epf_enable_inflation.body: Inflation reduces real purchasing power. Turn on inflation to view balances in today's money.

epf_rate_sanity_low.title: EPF rate looks unusually low
epf_rate_sanity_low.body: You entered {{r}}%. Double-check if the rate input is annual (not monthly) and whether you used the correct notified rate.

epf_tax_interest_on_excess_contrib.title: Interest may become taxable (employee contribution)
epf_tax_interest_on_excess_contrib.body: Your estimated employee yearly contribution is ~{{employeeAnnualContrib}}. This exceeds the threshold of ~{{threshold}} where interest on excess contributions may become taxable (rules can vary by year and conditions).

epf_inflation_warning.title: Inflation may reduce real growth
epf_inflation_warning.body: With inflation at ~{{infl}}%, real return is roughly ~{{real}}%/yr. EPF is a strong retirement anchor, but inflation still matters for long horizons.

epf_short_horizon.title: Short EPF horizon needs care
epf_short_horizon.body: For a horizon of ~{{years}} years, EPF withdrawals and tax treatment can be rule-dependent. Double-check eligibility conditions before planning early withdrawal.

home_loan_tax_new_regime.title: Home loan tax benefits may not apply (New regime)
home_loan_tax_new_regime.body: {{baseBody}} Under the New tax regime, many deductions are not available. Switch to Old regime in Advanced settings if you want to estimate tax benefit.

home_loan_tax_old_regime.title: Estimated home-loan tax benefit (Old regime)
home_loan_tax_old_regime.body: {{baseBody}} Under the Old regime, interest deduction may apply. Eligible interest considered ~{{eligibleInterest}}{{capNote}}, estimated tax saved ~{{estTaxSaved}}.

loan_rate_unrealistically_low.title: Rate looks unrealistically low
loan_rate_unrealistically_low.body: You entered {{r}}%. For a {{loanType}}, this looks {{why}}. Double-check if this is an introductory rate, a secured product, or if the rate input is monthly vs annual.

loan_high_roi_fallback.title: High interest rate for {{loanType}}
loan_high_roi_fallback.body: Your rate of {{input}}% is higher than the market median of {{median}}%.

loan_tenure_unrealistic_fallback.title: Tenure looks unrealistic
loan_tenure_unrealistic_fallback.body: A tenure of {{input}} years is uncommon for this loan type. Typical max is {{max}} years.

tenure_trap_fallback.title: Tenure increases total interest sharply
tenure_trap_fallback.body: At {{input}} years, you may pay ~{{ratio}}x of principal as interest (depends on rate).

prepayment_opportunity_fallback.title: Small prepayment can save years
prepayment_opportunity_fallback.body: Paying 1 extra EMI/year could reduce tenure by ~{{years_saved}} years.

od_high_utilization.title: High utilization makes OD behave like a term loan
od_high_utilization.body: Your average utilization is ~{{util}}%. When utilization stays high, OD loses its interest-saving advantage. Compare with a standard EMI loan to sanity check cost.

od_near_limit.title: You are close to the limit
od_near_limit.body: Peak utilization is ~{{util}}%. Running near the limit can increase risk of over-limit charges and reduce flexibility. Consider keeping a buffer or increasing repayments.

od_interest_only_trap.title: Interest-only can become a trap
od_interest_only_trap.body: If you only service interest (and don’t reduce principal), the outstanding can remain high for the full tenure. Adding even a small fixed monthly repayment can reduce total interest.

od_negative_cashflow.title: Withdrawals exceed deposits
od_negative_cashflow.body: Your monthly withdrawals are higher than deposits/repayment. This tends to increase outstanding over time and can push utilization higher.
